w:r.w:t: The teacher will teach basic greetings and introductions by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases: home, house, living room, kitchen, bedroom, bathroom, sit, eat, sleep, wash, I sit in the living room, I ea
t in the kitchen, I sleep in the bedroom, I wash in the bathroom
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for the house
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use sets of words in complete sentences
Word List: home, house, living room, kitchen, bedroom, bathroom, sit, eat, sleep, wash

Say the name of each room in a complete sentence:
Circle the correct room the teacher says
Read the names of the rooms with the student. Circle the names of the rooms as you say them. Encourage child to do the same.
Say one room name. By making a circle gesture with your finger, encourage the child to circle the name of the room you say. Encou
rage and model saying the name of the room in a complete sentence:
I sit in the living room
TPR: The teacher should stand up and then sit down while saying, “I sit in the living room.” Encourage the child to copy the phrase and action by gesturing to them.
TPR: The teacher should act out eating and say, “I eat in the kitchen.” Encourage the child to copy the phrase and action by gesturing to them.
TPR: The teacher should act out sleeping and say, “I sleep in the bedroom.” Encourage the child to copy the phrase and action by gesturing to them.
TPR: The teacher should act out washing hands and say, “I
in the bathroom.” Encourage the child to copy the phrase and action by gesturing to them.
Identify the rooms by circling them when the teacher does the action
Practice the spelling and reading the names of each room
The teacher should do the action for each room (sit, eat, sleep, wash) one at time. The student should circle and say the name of the room for each action. If child can, switch roles.
Write the name of each room one at a time. Encourage the child to rea
d the word and spell it with you.
Answer questions about where you sleep, eat, wash and sit
TPR: The teacher should use a puppet and model asking the puppet “Where do you
The teacher should model answering the puppet, “I sleep in the bedroom.” Encourage the child to answer, “Where do you sleep?” in the same way. Repeat the pattern with, “
Where do you eat?” “Where do you sit?” and “Where do you wash?” Students should answer in complete sentences.
Draw a line from the action to the room.

Ask the student, “Where do you sit?” Encourage the child to answer in a complete sentence, “I sit in the living room.”

Model counting the houses/homes with the student by checking the houses as you go. Have students count with you a second time.
Spell the word house and home and have students repeat after you.
Students should answer where they eat, sleep, sit and wash after the teacher shows prompts of each room:

Visual cue: Have props and pictures to show the students. Show a bowl of cereal and spoon. Pretend to eat and ask the student, “Where do I eat?” They should answer, “I eat in the kitchen.” Show a pillow and pretend to sleep on it. Ask the students, “Where
do I sleep?” They should answer, “I sleep in the bedroom.” Show the students your chair. Ask the students, “Where do I sit?” They should answer,
sit in the living room.” Show the students some hand soap. Ask, “Where do I wash?” They should answer,
Student will draw a line from the action to the room in the house.
The student will say the phrases (with an action):
The teacher will gesture with her finger by pretending to draw a line. She will ask the student to draw a line from the room to the action. The teacher can model the first one if necessary.
